column5: Description
An arrangement defined to fulfill the credit facility agreement
An arrangement into which is promised to deliver a specific service.. . Comment: Most service arrangements are instantiations of Product Services

A credit facility is a type of loan made in a business or corporate finance context. It allows the borrowing business to take out money over an extended period of time rather than reapplying for a loan each time it needs money. In effect, a credit facility lets a company take out an umbrella loan for generating capital over an extended period of time.. https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/creditfacility.asp
Types of credit facilities include revolving loan facilities, retail credit facilities (like credit cards), committed facilities, letters of credit, and most retail credit accounts.
The associated credit facility account number in any suitable format
The amount of the credit facility
The rate type to be applied to the credit facility
Key dates for the credit facility like Origination Date, Maturity Date and etc.

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
Date on which the agreement was signed by all parties. (ISO20022)

Specifies the category of agreement. Agreement type is very often referred to product. But, the term product does not cover all kinds of agreements. An Agreement can be subtyped from the perspective of various aspects of interest. One can classify the agreement from the perspective of format type (e.g., verbal agreement, written agreement). Other one can classify agreement based on duration like short-term agreement or long-term agreement.
Period during which the agreement is valid.
LifecycleStatus of agreement (e.g., potential, offered, confirmed, completed, signed, terminated)
The identifier of agreement like Agreement Number, Contract Number, Contract Registration Number, etc.

A characteristic of agreement which refers to 1) LifecycleDate of agreement (e.g., SignedDate, TerminatedDate, FulfilledDate) OR 2) ArrangedDate of agreement (e.g., StartingDate, EndingDate, ValidityPeriod, EffectiveDate).
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
A status which refers to the LifecycleStatus of arrangement (e.g., requested, proposed, offered, accepted, cancelled, terminated, fulfilled, etc.);
An arrangement into which is promised to deliver a specific service.. . Comment: Most service arrangements are instantiations of Product Services
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
An arrangement which specifies to charge fees when banking transactions did take place, accompanied by the modalities to calculate and charge the fees and the related terms and conditions.
A classification of fee according to the type of service. . Type of service for which a charge is asked or paid. (ISO20022)
Base amount that would be applied when the service is requested. . .
Rate used to calculate the amount of the adjustment, allowance, charge or fee. (ISO20022)
Period during which the fee is applicable. (ISO20022)
Date on which the fee needs to be paid.. - It is not nessessary a date and could be  expressed as a calander or formula or events that would be fulfiled.
An arranged FeeRatePlan.
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a loan account agreement. .
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement

An arrangement defining the applicable features for a savings account agreement. . . The arrangement type is one of those possible/mandatory for the sale of a savings account product. The actual arrangements are a selection of those offered under the savings account product.
Arrangement whitin the product sales agreement
ServiceArrangement defined for cash financial instruments like FeeArrangement, DepositArrangement, ...
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a Corporate Deposit Agreement. . .
An agreement established among the card holder and the card issuer to use the payment card for payment
InterestModality to calculate the interest. .
A method has to be used for calculating the interest
The periodicity of the calculation of the interest. (ISO20022).
The calculation date of the interest amount. (ISO20022)
A parameter used to calculate the interest.

Specifies whether the interest calculation method is simple or compounding. (ISO20022). . Simple: Calculation method by which interest is calculated on the original principal only. Accumulated interest from prior periods is not used in calculations for the following periods. (ISO20022). . Compounding: Calculation method by which interest is calculated each period on the original principal and all interest accumulated during past periods. (ISO20022)
A selection of interest product feature modalities for a specific interest arrangement in a specific agreemen
A (debt) Agreement specifying the terms and conditions for borrowing and lending a limited amount of money in the future.

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
An even that triggers the fulfilment of a fee arrangement.
Amount of fee that is charged. . . Amount of money that results from the application of an adjustment (charges. fees, discount or allowance) to the amount due. (ISO20022)
Date on which the fee needs to be paid.
Information about the fee transaction, such as reason, period, applied formula...
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
A service offered as a feature of a product.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
The type or category of product/service features
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
The identifier of product e.g. ISIN Code.
Specifies the category/type/class of product like financial product. Product can be categorized according to different perspectives.
Refers to the lifecycle of a product (e.g., initiated, announced, active, obsolete, withdrawn).
A detailed explanation or commentary of product.

A contract that gives rise to a financial asset of one entity and a financial liability or equity instrument of another entity. (IFRS). https://www.iasplus.com/en/standards/ias/ias32#:~:text=Key%20definitions%20%5BIAS%2032.11%5D,equity%20instrument%20of%20another%20entity. . Financial instruments are financial contracts of different nature made between institutional units. These comprise the full range of financial claims and liabilities between institutional units, including contingent liabilities like guarantees, commitments, etc. (ISO 10962).

An Agreement between two trading parties whereby one or more Assets are provided by a debtor as security for a payment or repayment of one or more obligations. (BIAN). . Comment: The subject matter of the agreement is securing payment". The most important arrangements are the collateral arrangements. But in the agreement are also price arrangements, period arrangements, fulfillment arrangements etc. agreed."
An identifier that allows to uniquely refer to an instance of a Collateral Agreement..
External identifier assigned by a collateral registration authority to refer to the registration of the collateral agreement.

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
A selection of repayment feature modalities for a specific repayment arrangement in a specific agreement
The schedule for repayments
An account for managing Credit Facility Arrangements.

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.. . Comment: . It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position.. The term account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions,. Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts.. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 € in cash, there is. a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased). an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased). . An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.. . Examples: . stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, .... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account. Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger . Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger.. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good.. A payment service to take fund out of an account. "

A type of credit vehicle in which a sum of money is lent to another party in exchange for future repayment of the value or principal amount.. https://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/loan.asp. . Loan vs Bond:. . Loan is a debt instrument where the lender is a financial institution and where the debt is not traded on the market. Bond is a debt that is traded on the bond market, the lender is not necessarily a financial institution , but one or more investors (a kind of crowd funding).

A Debt Instrument is a means someone can utilize to borrow  and return something according to specified terms and conditions.. . Comment: This something can be money, property, securities, rights, etc.. The terms and conditions includes details such as collateral, interest rate, schedule for interest payments, schedule for capital repayments, timeframe to maturity etc.. . What is the difference between debt instruments and equity instruments?. . Debt instruments are assets that require a fixed payment to the holder, usually with interest. Examples of debt instruments include bonds (government or corporate) and mortgages.. Equity instruments allow a company to raise money without incurring debt. This can include selling stock. When equity instruments are used, the holders give money in exchange for a portion of the company.. Debt holders usually charge businesses interest, while equity holders rely on stock appreciation or dividends for a return.
Arrangement of paying back money previously borrowed from a lender.
An agreement established among the card holder and the card issuer to use the payment card for payment
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a loan account agreement. .

A characteristic of account which refers to the LifecycleStatus of account like opened, closed, blocked, etc.
The identifier of account like Account Number.
A characteristic of account which refers to LifecycleDate of account (e.g., ClosingDate, OpeningDate, LiveDate, etc.)
Specifies the category of account like payment account, loan account, cash account, securities account, etc.

The state of the obligations managed on the account, the result of all entries on the account.. . Numerical representation of the net increases and decreases in an account at a specific point in time. (ISO20022). . Banking: Amount available in an account for withdrawal or use.. Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/balance.html. . Bookkeeping: Difference between the debit and credit sides of an account.. Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/balance.html
A detailed explanation or commentary of account. .
A record of events/entries..
A fulfillment of a specific interest arrangement
The amount of interest that is subject of this transaction
The InterestType of the Interest arrangement this is a transaction for
Interest amount that has accrued in between coupon payment periods. (ISO20022)
The date on which the interest has to be payed
Description of the transaction, such as applied interest rate, Interest period ...
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
The fulfilment of a repayment arrangement..
A selection of Fee Product Feature modalities for a specific fee arrangement in a specific agreement
Formula (calculation rule) used to calculate a charge/fee.
Specifies how charges are paid. (ISO20022)
Frequency at which the fee is charged
An arrangement into which both parties confirm on an interest product feature.
Type of an arranged Interest
An arranged InterestRate. . .
Type of Rate which is arranged to apply interest
Period during which the interest rate has to be applied.
An arranged InterestRatePlan
An interest schedule is an arranged/planned set of dates at which interest will be claimed.. . - The set can be represented on a calendar, a formula, a table, etc.

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee
Classification of the Money Transfer Instruction according to the event that lead to the instruction. . e.g. withdrawal, interest disbursement, direct debit, card payment.
Amount of money to be transferred.
Currency in which the transfer amount is expressed.
The reason why the instruction is given. . can be reference to a lot of information, concerning e.g. a purchase, an arrangement fulfillment event, a billing period...
The network to be used for the processing of the money transfer instruction as requested in the instruction.. e.g. instant SEPA?
The processing status of the instruction
Reference to the contact channel that was used to give the money transfer instruction
A request to do something.
An instruction to do something expressed in an amount of money.
An arrangement to limit something. e.g., the number of transaction per week, the amount of money allowed to withdraw per week/day and etc.
Nature of the limit.
Currency unit used to specify the limit amount. (ISO20022)
Period at which the limit is effective. (ISO20022)
Amount of money of the limit, expressed in a currency. (ISO20022)
Current status of the limit.
Specifies that the limit is a percentage of a related amount. (ISO20022)
Specifies the periodicity linked to a limit for example the periodicity can indicate that the limit can be reached daily or monthly. (ISO20022)
